Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Minority Youth and Everyday Negotiations of Place and Marginalization

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Researchers and policy makers have long been interested in understanding how growing up in impoverished neighborhoods impacts the life prospects of minority youth. As the gap between affluent and impoverished neighborhoods widens and as young adults remain stuck in poor urban communities, it has once again become imperative to understand how place shapes young people's aspirations and perceptions of their future. This project will address these questions by analyzing what urban minority youth learn about their community and how they use this knowledge to assess their future options and opportunities. Given the proliferation of place-based programs and policies geared to benefit youth in marginalized communities, this project will provide timely, policy-relevant information about the spatial factors most influential to structuring young people's aspirations and pathways to adulthood. The findings from this project will therefore inform urban reforms taking place within neighborhoods that have recently become part of a federally supported Choice Neighborhood program. The project will also contribute to efforts to create place-based indicators that capture young people's access to opportunities and prospects of attaining upward mobility. Additionally, by positioning young people's knowledge and perceptions as central to analyzing the effects of place, this project will generate theoretical insight that furthers our understanding of how particular places take on significance in shaping young people's lives and life course. In doing so, it will help advance geographical research on life course transitions and push sociological research on neighborhood effects to account for the everyday experience of growing up in a marginalized community.

The project blends literature from children's geography, social mobility, and life course studies to examine how young people's aspirations are shaped through their experiences in and of everyday places. Conceptually, the project frames young people's communities as formative geographies, learning spaces wherein they are absorbing information about their everyday surroundings and using this knowledge to evaluate the opportunities and pathways that are available to them and to people from their neighborhood. The study will explore how young people's everyday surroundings become formative by combining participant observations with go-along interviews to examine what African American and Latino/a youth have learned about their community and how that links to the way how they plan their lives. These methods will enable the researchers to gather in-depth, ethnographic information about what young people see, hear, say, and feel about the people, places, and spaces around them and observe the messages and advice they receive about how to grow up and get ahead in life. Semi-structured interviews will also be conducted with community members, teachers, and property managers who help construct young people's experiences of their community. Taken together, this methodological approach provides the spatialized perspective necessary to analyze how urban minority youth make sense of where they start out in life and evaluate what the possible pathways to success are from their particular social and spatial location.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The decline of intergenerational mobility and the likelihood that youth who grow up in poor communities will remain stuck in place is becoming an alarming and persistent trend. As the gap between affluent and impoverished neighborhoods widens, researchers and policy makers are striving to understand how place shapes young people’s aspirations and perceptions of their future. This project addresses these questions by examining what young people learn about their community and how that place-based knowledge links to the way they imagine and plan their lives. Specifically, the study examines how the marginalized neighborhoods of minority youth become formative, as they act as learning spaces wherein youth are absorbing information about their community, receiving messages about how kids from their part of town should grow up and get ahead in life, and are using this knowledge to assess their future options and opportunities.

 

For over two years, in-depth ethnographic data was gathered by engaging in and observing the daily lives of African American and Latino/Latina youth at a public housing community. Twenty-four walking tour interviews were also conducted with youth (9-17 years old) along with semi-structured interviews with parents, teachers, social workers, and community leaders. The findings from this research explain how the need to contend with the stigma of living in a marginalized neighborhood that is associated with diminished life outcomes creates early and persistently mixed messages that weakens young people’s ability to maintain high aspirations. The process of learning to view their neighborhood and future potential through the lens of stigma, and internalization of messages that reinforce the notion that you’re either one of the good kids (smart and headed toward success) or the bad kids (“ghetto” and on your way to ‘not making it’ in life), creates intense feelings of shame, anxiety, and resentment. These emotions and their consequences can pull youth toward accepting compromised aspirations as a way to cope with daily frustrations and external assaults to their self-confidence, and to combat the pain of lost opportunities and the loss of a possible—or former—self that could have been higher-achieving. These experiences of place stigma and shame, along with everyday trauma experienced in and through their neighborhood, emotional attachments to themselves and their futures in ways that compromises their ability to imagine and believe in upwardly mobile adulthoods. By detailing how these responses are produced through everyday experiences in and of marginalized neighborhoods, these findings also reveal how aspirations can emerge from the struggle to find a valued and tangible place from which to locate one’s identity and envision achievable pathways to successful futures.

 

Given the proliferation of place-based programs and policies geared to benefit youth in marginalized communities, this project provides timely, policy-relevant information about how place takes on significance in shaping young people’s aspirations and pathways to adulthood.
